div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK andamp; SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK andamp; SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE SCHOOL STRIKE.
div.p: The pupils of the School of Medicine have not yet carried out their threat of going on strike to express their sympathy with their companions of the Law School. It is to be hoped that prudent counsels will prevail, fora strike is, as Rusian experience shows, a double-edged weapon, and its orgnaisers may find themselves permanently the worse for having employed it. As for the strikers of the Law School, we believe that some of the regulations of whcih they complain are unduly sever. It is, for instance, rather unfair that a boy who fails in his first year's examination should have no second chance. But when the delegates of the strikers claim that every pupil who fails should be allowed to re-enter for teh examination for, we presume, an unlimited number of times,--no limit being specified in the list of demands sent by the delegates to the Ministry of Public Instruction,-- then we shall have middle-aged failures coming up with deplorable regularity for the same examination that proved too mcuh for them in their salad days-Cairene imitations of the woe-begone personages of comparatively advanced age, who appear at stated intervals from the depths of the country at our British universities on precisely the same errand. In our opinion the strikers might have edited their demands. They compalin of afternoon work-but at the School of Medicine work last all the day and the upils of the Polytechnic have thier eight hours. Demands of this nature are simply inadmissable, and if the students have another edition of their Bill of Rights to forward to teh authorities we recommend them, as future lawyers, to draft it carefully.

There is another point to which we should like to draw the attention of the strikers. A statement is current, and was reproduced by a Cairo contemporary, to the effect that a European lady whp rashly endeavoured to speak was "conspuee et expulsee." We hope that this story is, at least, exaggerated if not unfounded, otherwise we cannot congratulate the students of the Law School, who have been described to us as capable and intelligent young men of superior class, on their chivalry or good manuers. A polite refusal is always possible in such casesm but if a woman is to be spat upon and driven away for expressing a desire, however eccentric, to harangue a meeting of students, one begins to wonder whether the proverb "Grattez le Russe," with the necessary alterations caused by the comparative proximity to Egypt of the Nyam country, may not be applicable to some of our young Cairenes. For the future let even excited students try to remember that to be on strike against the educational authorities does not absolve them from the usages of common courtesy.

As the outcome of experiments made by some of the largest of the English railways it has been found that the temperature of Railway compartments is raised 3 degrees Fahrenheit by the use of oil gas giving a light equal to 13 candle power. In these days, when the public are calling for an increase in the amount of light supplied in railway carriages, it would be interesting to ascertain what would be the increase in temperature by lighting a dining car with oil gas giving a candle power equal to that now afforded by electric light on the best British Railways, vix: upwards of 400 c.p. Surely a thermometer under such circumstances would indicate "fever heat." 36980-1

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: Turkey has improved a medical inspection on arrivals from Alexandria.

div.head: Cyprus Cable
div.p: Telegraphic communication between Alexandria and Cyprus is interrupted.

div.head: Black Diamond Minstrels
div.p: A rehearsal by the Black DIamond Ministrels will take place this evening at 9 o'clock at the Rudolph Home.

div.head: Alexandria Harbour
div.p: Yesterday's Journal Offiiel" contains the regulations now in force fo "berthing, mooring, stationing, shifting and circulation of ships in the port of Alexandria."

div.head: Egyptian Constructions, Limited
div.p: We are informed that this issue has been coverd ten times over at Cairo and five times over at Alexandria. The applications for shares aggregated nearly 900,000.

div.head: Khedivial Georgraphical Society
div.p: There will be a meeting of the society on Saturday next at 4 p.m. in the hall of the Cairo Mixed Courts. M. Colrat will elcture on Tunis and French colonisation.

div.head: Fire at Damanhour
div.p: A fire broke out at Damanhour in a sugar cane store owing to teh usetting of a lamp on Tuesday evening but was extinguished by the police before much damage was done.

div.head: Beacon Washed Away
div.p: Information has been recieved from the Controllet of Ports, Sudan Government, that the beacon on the north end of Towartit Reef has been washed away, but will be replaced as soon as possible.

div.head: Imperial Ottoman Bank
div.p: Mr. I Rossi, the fonde de pouvoirs of the bank at Alexandria has been transferred to another post and been replaced by Mr. H. Willner. The latter has been replaced aas chef des positions by Mr. E Papasian.

div.head: Khedivial Honours
div.p: A second list of decorations conferred on the occasion of the anniversary of the Khedive's accession was issued yesterday. The only European among thr recipients is Mr. Nicholas Choremi Greek merchant at Port Said (Medjidieh 4h class).

div.head: Land Deal
div.p: The property formerly owned by Messrs. Hinshlelwood, opposite the European Hospital, ALexandria, changed hands yesterday at the price of P.T. 350 a pic. The property consists of 4.210 pics and the purchases are the Societe Egyptienne d'Enterprises Urbaines et Rurales.

div.head: A Nile Tragedy
div.p: News comes from Dessouk that a boat was sailing on the Nile yesterday with a numebr of passegners on board when it collided with a steamer. The boat capsized and sank an, all on board were drowned. The Dessouk Markaz authorities promptly appeared on the scene and after some labour 12 corpses were recovered from the Nile. There are some bodies as yet unrecovered.

div.head: The Moltke's "Wireless" News
div.p: During the voyage of the Hamburg-American liner Motlke, which brought 360 tourists to Alexandria from New York and Genoa, the vessel was constantly in communication with the Marconi wireless station at the Lizard, and the most important news of the day was recieved by wireless, printed and distributed to the passengers. The wireless apparatus of the Motlke has a radius of 1,800 miles.

div.head: Delta Land, Ltd.
div.p: Mr. J.A.W. Peacock, late chief engineer of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limite, has been defintitely appointed manager of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, Mr Peacock was the doyen of the Del a Light Railways, having been with that company from its inception. Beofre that he was on the Smyrna-Kanaba line and has had considerable business experiences in the Levant. The appointment has given general satisfaction.

div.p: By kind permission of Lieut-Colonel R.C.C. Cox commanding, and officers 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the band will perform the follwoing selection of music on the terrace on the National Hotel on Friday afternoon from 4 to 6 pm. March-Trumpets of the Guard-Williams Overture--La Neige-Auber Entr'acte-Rose Mousse-Bose Selection-Mikado-Sullivan. Valse-Eldorado--Royle. Patrol-Rose Shamrock and Thistle-Sousa. Selection-Boccaccio--Supper. Song-A Child's Song of Hope-Myddleton. Regimental March-Khedival Anthem. God Save the King.

Markham and and officers the band of the 1st King's Royal Rifles will perform the following selection of music at the Helouan race meeting tomorrow:-- March-Belphegor--Brepsant Overture-The Bohemian Girl--Bafle Selection--My Lady Molly-Jones Gavotte--Stephanie--Czibulka. div.head: The NAVY Estimates; Government Policy
div.p: Although the Naval Estimates for the coming year have beem reduced by 500,000, Lord Tweedmouth, realizing the importance of the Navy is practically following the policy of the previous Governmetn, thus placing the question of the Navy above party strife.

div.head: Alexandria Unshaved; Barber's Strike
div.p: While at Cairo the pupils of the School of Law are on strike, Alexandria ahs not been behind, and this morning the employes of the hairdressers and barbers steuck work. These men have a strong union known as the Barbers' League (Lega dei Barbieri). For some time past the members of this league have been agitating for shorter hours, and a few days ago tehy sent a circular to the proprietor of hairdresser shops demanding a fixed working day of from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. with two hours' rest in the middle of the day. No reply was recieved and yesterdau evening a mass meeting of the barbers' assistants in Alexandria and Ramleh was held at the headquarters of te league in the Haymarket, when it was decided to consider the circular as an ultimatum and to declare a general strike to-day.

This morning many Alexandrians had per force to go unshaved and great inconvenience was experienced by those perons who are unable to shave themselves. Them men are resolved to fight to the bitter end for they declare that they are much overworked and never know when they can return home in the evening.
The league will distribute strike pay to the men as it is fairly strong fianncially. Up to the time of going to press up negotiations has as yet been opened between the masters and men.

div.head: Alexandria Municipality
div.p: Mr. Barbaza was yesterday returned unopposed as third member of the Municpal College of Importers, polling 134 votes.

div.head: A German Fete
div.p: Owing to the non-arrival of the North German Lloyd liner Hohenzollern, the fete which was to have been given on board that steamer by Mr. Hellwig, German Vice-Consul, had to be abandone . The Captain of the Hamburg American liner Moltke, however, fillwed the breech and kindly offered his ship, with the result that baout 120 members of the German colony were able to celebrate the silver wedding of their Kaiser in a fitting manner. The fete was a great success in every way. The captain of the Moltke, notwithstanding the short time available, had managed to decorate the ship in a very tasteful and artisitc manner. the festivities began at 7:30pm. and lasted till midnight, Mr. Hellwig's guests sitting down to a well served dinner. The toast of the evening that of the Kaiser and the Imperial Family, was given by Mr. Hellwig. Mr. H. Bindernagel proposed the Vice-Consul's health and Mr. O. Rotbhacker drank to the success of the Humnburg-American Line. The ship's orchestra, composed of 20 performers, performed at intervals during the evening.

div.head: The Sudan Frontier; Question in Parliament; Establishment of Congo Posts.
QUESTION IN PARLIAMENT. ESTABLISHMENT OF CONGO POSTS.
div.p: In the House of Commons last week Sir. C. M'Laren asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether his attention had been called to the nature of the attacks recently made by the troops of the Congo State upon the Sudan frontier, and if he would say what steps he proposed to take.

Mr. Runciman(Parliamentary Secretary to Local Governemnt Board) said: His Majesty's Government have no information as to any attacks having recently been made by troops of the Congo State on the Sudan frontier or as to any fighting having occured. Certain posts have been established within territory considered by his Majesty's Government as indisputably belonging to the Sudan, and his Majesty's Governemnt are in communication with the Government of the Congo the subject.

div.head: Bahr El Ghazal "Mutiny"
div.p: The mutiny in the Baht el Ghazal resolves itself into a drunken freak by a soldier of the 10th, Sudanese Battalion, who, after copions libations of "buza," let off his rifle in all directions and wounded an Egyptian officer in the foot. The drunken private of the Blacks was promptly arrested.

div.head: The Nour EL Bahr.
div.p: H.H.S. Nour el Bahr arrived from Akaba this afternoon at 1.35, and will sail again for that port next friday morning.

div.head: The DUNERA
div.p: The hired transport Dunera arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Crete and Cyprus with four companies of the 1st King's Royal Rifle Corps, which left for Cairo by special train this morning.

div.head: The School Strike
div.p: We hear on going to press that the students of the Kasr el Aini Hospital have thought better of their threat to go on strike.
A meeting was held this morning at the Ministry of Public Instruction with reference to the strike of the Law School.

div.head: Freemasonry in Egypt
div.p: Idris Pacha Ragheb is resigning his position as Grand Master of Mark Masonry in the District of North Africa, which he has held for the last nine years. His Excellency will, we understand, be succeeded by Crockshank Pacha, Past Deputy District Grand Master. This appointment will be recieved with general approval throughut Egypt.
The President of the Supreme Council of the Scottish Rite for Egypt and its dependencies, Mr. Abramino Tilche, has resigned. Baron Felix de Menadce has been unanimously selected to replace him.

On Tuesday evening the members of the Rising Sun Losge (No. 91 Eg. Constitution) held thier annual installation meeting to instal the W.M. elect Bro. A.J. Roche, S.W. There was a very good attendance. Amongst those present we noticed Rt. W. Bro. Brewster Bey, W.M. Idris Lodge; W. Bro. E. Lambton Dist. G. Secretary D.G.L. of Egyot and the Sudan; Bro. King, the outgoing W.M. perfomed the installation ceremony in a most able manner, which was testified to by hearty applause on its complettion.

The newly installed W.M. invested his officers as follows: W. Bro. Beale., S.W.; Rt. W. Bro, Snithard, J.W.; Rt Wor. Brewster Bey, tresurer (re-elected); Bro. Chesters, secretary, W. Bro. Lumsden, S.D.; Bro. Freeman, J.D.; Bro. Anderson, D. of C.; Bro. Sfer, organist; Bro Feldman, J.G. and Bro. Jacob, tyler. VW. Bro Norman-Lee. P.G. Ch, was unanimously re-elected chaplain but was unavoidably prevented from attending to be invested.
The accoutns shewd a substantial cash balance and considering tha the lodge was only inaugurated a year ago its members are to be congratulated on their management of the lodge.

Wishes were recieved from the National Grand Lodge of Egypt, the Dist. G.L. of Egypt and the SUDAN. Eston Lodge, Bulwer, Greece. Albert Edward, Zetland, Sir Reginald Wingate, English Constitution, Nos. 48, 51, 74 Egyptian Constitution, 76 and 266 Irish, 450 and 439 Scotch, etc. for the continued success and prospertity of the lodge.

The members, together with their friends, adjourned to teh Grand Continenta Hotel, where a supper was provided. The usual loyal and Masonic toasts were heartily received. and the goodfellowship and brotherly feeling which existed prove that there is very much in Freemasonry as practised on the banks of the Nile.

div.head: Steamer Movement
div.p: The Cunard S.S. Tyria arrived here yesterday and is now on the berth loading cargo or Liverpool and American ports.

div.head: GHEZIREH CASINO. THE BAL MASQUE. A KALEIDOSCOPE OF COLOUR.
div.p: The much-talked of fancy ball at Ghezireh Palace is one of the memories of the past, and on of the very pleasantest memories of the seasn according to the unanimous of opinion of all those who attended it. It would be hard to find a more beautiful setting for the variegated costumes than the Casino with its brightly coloured hangings and comfortable lounge and its richly deocrated suite of rooms. As for the dancers and their various attires, words, fail to exress their infinite variety, and brain was equally incompetent to keep pace with all that motley crowd that filled the ballroom an overflowed into the ante rooms. Pierots and pierrettes, soldiers in every period of uniform, national costumes of all sorts, country lads and merry partners, mummers and historical characters, not to mention the host of grotesques, flitted across one's range of vision and mingled again with the kaleidoscope of colour till one's ete was weary and one;s mind a hopeless jumble. A certain number of figures remain distinct amont the otehrs, and chief among these may be reckoned the beautiful Mlles. Zakreveski who wore the gorgeous COurt dress of their country, their satin growing with sparkling bands veiled by the long gauze draperies hanging from the high jewelled diadems, rows and rows of pearls from the head-dress round their faces. young and very beautiful, and wearing the richest costumes in the room, there was no doubt where the honours of the evening were due. It was more difficult to award the palm to the best masculine costume, but perhaps the sparkling suit of silver tissue worn b Lieut. Adams as a Knight Templar with its white cloak and blood-red cross was the most admired. There were many clowns and pierrots and their lady counterparts, some in all white, some in magpie, some in parti-coloured coons, anf a plethora of both Chinese and Indian dresse. There was a corenr in bath toweling too; one officer belonging to the Egyptian Army was in a very well made kill of this useful material a cake of soap serving to fasten his plaid upon the shoulder, and his sporran decorared with three shaving brushes. A second figure was clad in Kimona, girt round the waist with his bath towel and his hea surmounted by a large sponge, and a third was purely grotesque his draperies being of towels weighted with sponges, and a little sponge with antennae of Isofah, parched upon his forehead. A headsman in black hidden behind a mask, and carrying the horrid instrument of his profession, seemed to find some difficulty in finding-partners; not so the buxom school girl with long golden curls and sun bonnet who commenced by dnacing with men, but soon wearied of the novelty and returned to his usual partners. There were some excellent Bedouin Arabs and Turkish dress, who had hidden themselves behind yashmaks of more or less transparency. Mrs. Nolan was one of these latter, and her little pink turban and soft swathing of tulle over her face only serve to enhance its delicate colouring. Miss revs made very commanding and effective Ententes Cordiale, with her scarlet cap of liberty, and the flags of the countries appearing in harmony on her skirt and corsage. Mrs. Nungovich, representnng wither gold-or la fasitaisie, was magnificent in a sparkling rohe of Assiout shawl tissue, an enormous golden aht with upstanding plumes upon her head, and countelss rows of gold pealrs and chains hanging from the hat. Miss Nungovich made a singularly sprightly Columbine in short white skirts and pretty cocked hat. The Misses York were poudree, as were many others, Miss Hervey looking especially handsome in her white wig. Miss Hemming looked her best as "lily of the Valley" in a dress of silver tissue trimmed with flowers a lily coup forming her head dress, Miss Blythe looked charming as Margerite with chaptlet of peals upon her head, and her sister was the second Etent Coridale noticed in the room. Miss Boulter went in French peasant dress and peasant dresses of various sorts were worn by the Misses Hurley as Dutch girls and by Mrs. Morgan as a Swiss girl. MR. hUESTON LOOKED as a red cross sister and MiSS. smART, TOO, LOOKED, VERY TRIM TO THE MANNER FBORN HIN HER NURSE dress. the Misses Coles were attired as Christmas crackers, and Mr. Siballi made a most excelletn Napoleon with but little make-up required to give him this facial resemblence. There were various Japanese ladies, but none more succesffulyly attried than Miss lampson and Miss Crofton, as the "Spirirt of teh Casino," carried many of the emblens of the roulette table. several gentle men were glad in white evening suits with black accesories; one of them had put his clothes wrong side in front, and his gold watch chain hung across his waist post on the small of his backk. SPace frobids a longer mention of the otehr costumes. Suffice to say it was of the best ball of its kind ever witnessed in Ghezireh, and reflected the greatest credit on the ingenuuity of those who took part in it. Hemming lloked her best as "lily of the Valley" in a dress of silver tissue trimmed with flowers, a lily cup forming her head-dres, Miss Blythe looked charming as Margnerite with chaplet of pearls upon her head, and her sister was the second Entente Cordiale noticed in the room. Miss Boulter want in French peasant dress, and peassant dresses of various sorts were worn by the Misses as a Swiss girl. Mr. Huetson looked as a Red Cross Sister and Miss Smart, too, looked very trim to the manner born in her nurse's dress. The Misses Coles were attired as Christmas crackers and Mr. Sibelli made a most excellent Napolean with but little make-up required to giv him the facial resemblance. There were various Japanese ladies, but none more successfully attired than Miss Lampson, and Miss Crofton, as the the "Spirit of the Casino," carried many of the emblems of the roulette table. Severla gentle men were clad in white evening suit with black accessories; one of them had put his clothes wrong side in front, and his gold watch chain hung across his waist coat on the small of his bacl. SPace forbids a longer mention of the other costumes. Suffice to say it was the best ball of its kind ever witnessed it Ghezireh, and reflected the greatest credit on the ingennity of those who took part-in it.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ART. AN INTERESTING PERIOD. PROFESSOR PETRIE;S LECTURE (from a correspondent)
div.p: All who are interested in ancient Egyptian art owe a debt of gratitude to Professor Petrie for his lecture on the period durng which Thebes reached the height of her power and splendour. The previous lecture had dealt with the long period of artistic degeneration which began during the reign of Ramesse II. and which in spite of the Saite revival lasted till the death of the natioanl art. Naturally, in the exquisite work of the XII. dynasty and the noble monuments of the XVIII. Prod. Petrie had a more pleasing theme and he dealt with it in a manner which made it a priviledge to hear him. Few period in the history of the world are of more engrossing interest than the days of Egypt's glory, an few periods of art are so misunderstood and misinterpretated. This is largely becasue much of the work that is best known to the general public belongs to the later and degenerate productions of the Ramesside kings, and this effect is increased by the reproductions in books which have become familar but which give no true idea of the original. Probably no drawing in so delicate and so hard to reproduce accurately as the Egyptian designs, even in their conventional pictures, and in this connexion Prof. Petrie's collection of photographs made into latern slides was especially valuable. Not only has his vast knowledge of the musuems of all countries enabled him to choose the best illustrations which are available. but his photographic skill ahs enabled him to present his examples in the most favourable manner possible. The first slide showed a relief of the beginning of the XIth dynasty, and was a proof of the depths to which art had sunk since the days of the kings who ruled at Memphis. The rise however of anew and beatutiful style during the the XIth dynasty was rapid. From the Days of Herodotus till the present time so much has been said abiut the continuity of Egyptian style, that it has beem generally assumed that Egyptian art underwent little or no change from the earliest to the latest times. How contrary to fact this theory actually is can be seen at once by comparing the work of the Sakkara tombs with that of the XII. dynasty at Koptos. The head of Usertesen I. is one of the best examples of portraiture in the First Theban Empire which we possess, and shows clearly the chief characteristics of that school. In it we see certain mannerisms of style: the work is not copied from nature so directly as in the time of the IVth dynasty: it shows a delicacy of modelling and a power of indicating what it does not fully express which reminds us of what is now called impressionalist art. This forms a contrast to the stern simplicity which is the pervading note of the great monuments of the early empire.

Other reliefs of great beauty were them thrown upon the screen, and in them too the samr traits were conspicuous. Much of their effct is gained from tehir very low relief, much lower than any which had been previously attempted, and which can be appreciated only if seen in an exactly appropriate light. Of a lighter and freer character were some ivory carvings some of which represented "genre" scenes and which testify to the tarte of the Egyptians even in minor objects. Prof. Petrie then discussed the famous Dashur jewellery and showed in succession the three wonderful pectorals which are among the greatest treasures of the musuem. Such a comparison of objects of a similar size and nature is most instructive in watching the rise or decline of art: an examination of these three pectorals belonging to three successive kings is as suggestive as the comparison of the coins or seals of different reign European history. The first, which belongs to the very beginning of the XII dynasty, is by far the best. In design, execution, and adaptation to the end in view it is alike admirable. The frame is exactly suited to the design and is broad enough to give th assurance of stregnth to the composition. The Royal Hawks have a simple dignity and the required space is filled to perfection. The next in date represents two hawks headed sphinxes trampling on Asiatic and Ethiopian enemies. Here the design is still good and the general effect pleasing; there is not, however that perfect in the preceding work. For exmaple, the pants which form the sides of the frame are graceful anf are happily introduced, but they scarcely form a strong enough framework for the pectoral. In the third we see a complete loss of the power of filling a space with corrrect line, the very essence of design. The two figures of the king clubbing his foes are well drawn in themselves but the artist has crowded far too much into the narrow borders of his composition, he has heaped an ornament under the delusion that he was adding beauty. During thr XII Dynasty art gradually but steadily declined still we reach the period of the still mysterious Shepherd or Hyksos Kings. The sphinxes and other works which bear the names of some of these invaders are almost certainly earlier monuments which have been engraved with cartouches during the Dark Ages of Egyptian history. Probably the actaul Hyksos have left us no monuments at all. When these foreign tribes had been at ast expelled, Egyptian art experienced a great revival. During the XVIII. dynasty the influence of the drawing and designing schools is even more apparent than during the XII. The styler of this period depends much rule and tradition; an atist was more concerned with exactly obeying his canon than with producing a work true to life, the result is smooth and easy finish but in all but the best examples an certain los in feeling and vitality. Even at Abydos in spite or the undeniable excellence of the work this defect is manifest. Still the succeeding lantern slides showed to what a very high level the art of the period attained. Very interesting also were some specimens of work from the art schools which had be carved for practice or as a practical illustration of the artist's skill.

In the reign of Queen Tyi a great change came over the artistic spirit of the country. Previous to this time Egyptian art had alternately progressed and receded in different ways but with the same general tendency. When however Egypt conquered Syria works of art but also great soon made themselves felt. At the same time aslo Greek vase were being imported into Egypt is lrge quantities and these too helped to modify the ancient and traditional ideas.

These influences are nowhere found more clearly than in the potrait of Queen Tyi herself which Prof. Petrie found last winter in the temple at Sarabit in the Sinai peninsula. This beautiful little head shows more of a passing mood as opposed to the permanent and essential character than we have hirthero met in Egyptian portraiture. The delicacy with which the feeling and personality of the queen is expressed entitles this little portrait to a high place in the art not only of Egyot; but the world.

The XVIII dynasty was a time of great personal wealth and luxury among the upper midle class of Egyptians. The organisation and government of the empire required a vast number of officials, so rhar we find more wealth in private tombs in this period than any other. Especially beautiful are some wooden spoons of various designs: in these and in wooden statuettes of little girls we see a freedom and grace which was necessary curtailef in the more formal monuments of granite. Perhaps the most remarkable of this series is the little ebony negress photographed by Prof. Petrie, with the light cunningly reflected by mirrors that the surface modelling is clearly shown. Some very pleasing drawings were also exhibited in which the firm soie brushwork with tis bold though delicate curves and lines gave a chracter and decision which our best draughtsmen well might envy. The lecture ended with a fine photograph of the black granite statue at Turin of Rameses II. executed at the beginning of his reign. This is the last example of the great masterpieces of Egyptian art.

Great as was the value and interest of this lecture it is with even greater expectation that we await the next of the series, that of the less known but even more wonderful period of the early Empire, concerning which Prof. Petrie's knowledge is unique. All who are interested in history or in art should make an effort to be present.

div.head: PERSONAL AND Social
div.p: It is stated that Baron Rucker-Jenisch has been transferred as Germans Minister to the Grand Duchy of Hesse-Damstadt. His successor has not been appointed yet, so far as is known. Great regret will be felt at the departure of the popular German Minister and his charmng wife from Cairo, where they will leave a most pleasany souvenir.

On board of the S.S. Hohenzollern, which, as already announced, did not arrive on Monday owing to an accident to her machinery, are Mr. and Mrs. von Hartmann and their children. Mr. von Hartmann, who was formerly German Consul here is now Consul-General at Naples. He and Mrs, von Hartmann were on their way out here owing to the death of the latter's brother, Mr. Hans von Techudi.
Mrs. Phillipps and Miss Philipps have left Stoke d'Abernon to spend the remainder of the winter in Egypt.
Sir Alexander Baird has also come here.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe last night:--Mr. and Mrs. Gordon, Mr. Ireland and party of 3, Mr. Chancly and party of 3, Messrs.A.H. Perknos and H.D. Thompson, Mr. Koch and party of 3, M. and Mme De Lalpin, Cook's Moltke party of 16.

div.head: SPORT AND Play
div.p: POLO TOURNAMENT.
THE GORDON CUP.
FIRST GAME.

The 2nd and 3rd ties in the Gordon Cup were played off on Monday afternoon before a large crowd of spectators. There was a na^ly wind biowine which intei fared considerably wiih the polo. The second game between the Tourists and-Freebooters was much the better game, the polo at times being quite good. The Egypt- ian Army were unlucky as Captain Rome was eutiering from a sprained wrist which handicapped him a lot.
60th R ties v. Egyptian Army.
Major Eustaoe. Capt. Rome.
Mr. Dalby. Capt. Bnskenridge.
Mr. Seymour. Capt. Broadbent
Mr. Pardop. Capt. Gordon.
Umpire. -Mr. Dunbar.
FIRST CHUKKER.

The 60th were first cu the ball'from the throw-in. Broadbent returned aud the ball was taken to the 60th goal. Dalby cleared and Eustaoe and Sevmour backing up well relied the ball to the E. A. goal, wb we a good chance was missed. F.om a me'iSs in front of goal the 60th again lost a good chance cf scoring. Some uninteresting polo followed and from another meMo Eustace scored a goal. Up and down play followed till the 60th getting hold of the ball in midfield ran the ball up and Seymour hit a goal. Result of chukker : 60th, 2 goals: E.A. nil.
2ND CHUKKER.

The 60th got the ball from the "hrow in. Dalby made a good run bat" his final shot went wide behind. From the hit outSeymour returned and Eustace slipping Rome, bin a goal. Scrambling plaj fiUowed till Dalby got possessiou a> d made a good ran dowu the ground bat again hie fi ial shot went wide. 6 Uh, 3 goals; E A., nil. *
3RD CHUKKER.

From the hit-out Broadbent ran the ball down the ground butSeymour-retarned we'l and the 60th, rushing the ball up, scored a goal After the throw-in Rome got away and look ed like sooriDg.bnt misdna.the ball was retarned and Eastace made a good run, but his final shot wpnt very wide, — a good chanoe lost. From the hit-out the E. A. backed eaoh other up well and rushing the ball down to the 60th goal looked likesuoring.butSeymoor cleared well. Up and down play followed in mid- field till Rome dnbaircepted'the ball and slip, ping the field brought off a good ran. His final shot, however, went wide,—a good ohahee missed. Result ofCh ikker: 60th,4goals,E. A.,nil. From the hit out D dby ran the ball down, but Brakenridge returned well. Scrambling play followed till Rome got hold and feeding his forwards well,'the E.A. took thb ball'down the gr iund and a goal seemed certain, j but Seymour saved with a fi.ie shot and Palby made a goci run to the E.A. goal but hit behind. Result 60th, 4 goals ; E.A., nil.
SECOND GAME.
Freebooters v. To units.
Capt. Kennedy Mr. Paravioini
Capt. Protheroe Smith Mr. P ckving
Mr. Dunbar Mr. De Freville
Mr. Rumbold Col. Sparkes
Umpire—Capt. Bartlett.
1ST CIIUKKER.

From the throw-in the Freebooters were the first to get on the ball and Rambold hit a aa'o9:diary. Sparkes hit oat to Piokerin/, who made a good run up the ground, his final-shot going wide. Very fast play folo*ed, the ball travelling up and down the ground at a great paoe. Pickering g >fc possession at midfield and with two huge smites nearly scored a goal, Rambold saving well. Dunbar then brought the ball dowu the groand and centered beautifully, bat Pickering again got possession and brought the ball back. Again the ball was carried back to the Tourists' goal when Protheroe Smith hit a subsidiary from a different augle. Result: Freebooters, 2 subs ; Tourists, nil. A very good fast galloping ohukker with good combination on both sides.
2ND CHUKKER.

From the hit-ont the tourists raD the ball up, but Rumbold returned and Dunbar feeding bis number 2 well,' Protheroe Smith hit' a goal. First np-and down play followed, Paravioini with a good 'stroke,almost Feared. Rumbold saved wail, but Pickering followed up, hit tie ball through rather a lucky goal off a pony's Teg. From the throw in the Tourists took the ball down to Freebooters \goal, when a lot of sorurn- uiaging took place. Finally the Freebooters cleared, and Sparkes getting bold made a good ran bat hit wide. Shortly afterwards Sparkes again made a good yun and hit a very eood goal from a dilfi jblt angle. Result: Freebooters, 1 goal, 2 subs ; Tourists, 2 goals. Not such a good chukker, neither so fast nor sirch good combination Bhown as in the first.
3RD CHUKKER. )

From the throw-in the Freebooters Yan the ball up but Sparkes returned well. Up-and- down play folowel.. Dunbar, and Sparkes pntting in a lot of good work: The game wa- r.ow for tha rno->t part th* Tourists' eud, and the latter fouling gave the Freebooters a free bit at the goal. Danbar took the hit bat Pickering mat the ball and cleared, but it was only temporary relief as the Freebooters again attaoked and Protheroe Smith hit a subsidiary. Just at the en l of the chukker the Tourists rushed the ball down the ground and scored a goal. Result ; Freebooter^ 1 goal, 3 subs ; Tourists, 3 goals. A good obukkor in wbioh play for the most part was confined to the Tourists' end of the ground.
4Tn GIIUKKFR

F.-om the throw-in the Toarisls ran the ball down bi t Rumbold saved well. First up-and- down play followed which ended in Paravioini hitting a good subsidiary. Tha Freebooters then looked like sooring. From a good oentre by Paravioini Pickering took the ball on well and Rumbold again saved very well. Again the Freebooters attacked and Kennedy jast missed scoring. The bell rang with the play in mid- field. Result : Freebooters, 1 goal 3 pets ; Tourists, 3 grials 1 set.x'v

This was -a real good game and qaite the best we have seen so far. Tuere wa9 little tq qhoose between the teams as the score indicates. For-the winners Sparkes played well and was very safe at back. Both De Freville and Paravioini have oome on a lot and played well, also Pickering made several good runs, bis hitting being very powerful. For the losers Rumbold aud Dunbar played best. We have □aver seen the loriuer play better. The latter perhaps did not play up to his reputation, but his ponies we daresay were responsible for that. YOQ cannot expect ponies to race one day and play polo the next.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The S. S. Dnrera, which leaves Alexandri this week with three omp*nieT of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inni«ki lngFusiliera^for Crete and one for Cyprus, will return again 1 Alexandria wi b font rompanifs of the \ Battalion King's Roytl R fle Corps from the same stations, and wh-oh rejoin headqnarters at Cairc. Th« headquarters and remaining half battalion of the 1 uniskillings remain at Cairo

The 1st Battalion East Yorkshire Regiment has jast arrived horns from India after over 20 years' service abroad. It went to Gibraltar from England in 188.\ to the West Indies in 1886, to South Africa in 1888, to Egypt in 1893, and from the latter country it went to "Tbq Shiny" in 1895, and served there up till its embarkation for home. It is stationed at ShorncliSe.

Captain H. du B. O'Neill, Beutordshire Regiment, who for some time has been success fully employed under the Colonial Offioe as company officer of the 6th Batalion King's African Rides in Somaliland, has been appoint-to that battalion at Berbers. Capta n O'Neill was mentioned in despatches for his services in the stiff operations in the Somaliland, 1901 02, and reoeived the medal with o'asp.

The Army Connoil has decided to re-arm the battalions of tho 13th Infantry Brigade (1st Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, 1st Battalion Royal Iru.h Furiliere, 1st Battalion Qaepp's Own Camoron Higlanders, and 2nd BattalionRoyallrish RifleB) atDnblin and 14th Infantry Brigade (4th Battalion Royal War wickshire Reriment, 14th Battalion R^yal Fas(iiers, 1st Battalion Sonth Staffordshire Regiment, and 1st Battalion East Lancashire Regiment), at the Carragh with the short mage tine L^e-E .field rifle, together with the charger, psokal amxni'.wtiou and bandolier equipment. At the same time, the depots of the above battalions will receive the short rifle aod bandolier equipment for the instruction of recruits and reservistt. When the e two brigades are re-armed 42 battalions on borne service, including the Brigade of Guatda, will be in possession of the short riflt and equipment.

The Army Cmncil has decided that on the termination of the period of appointment of an Instructor of Gunnery, 1st or 2nd olass, a report is to be made by his immediate superior rffioer direct to the Command int, Sonool of Gunnery, stating whether th« officer is recommended for re-appointment in a higher capacity, and detailing any special qnalifi- oation which be may have shown for each employment.

The Army Connoil has intimated that in the fptqre the initial rate of pay of ex-sol Her olerks. employed in Army Service Corps or Staff offices will be twenty fonr shillings p-r week, rising by triennial increments of thre shillings per week.-Ordinarily two snob inore menta will be given, and the maximum will thus be thirty shillings p«-r week, as in the new JReoord offices. This maximum will, however, be open to re consideration at a later date, if, in special oases, owing to the nature of the work, it may be deemed necessary to give a farther increment of pay.

Sincere regret is ex; reused everywhere at the rather sodden death of Vice-Admiral Harry T. Grenfell, the capable seoond in com mand of the Mediterranean Fleet. He was a very smart officer,and had seen service in th Egyptian War, 1882, and the Navy to-day i^ considerably poorer by bis demise.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The past week hts brought no change in the monetary position. Stringency is the prevailing tenor, and loans still command 4 % for the usual periods. Theye has bean no addition to the supply of loanable funds, and those who were looking for easier conditions on the 21st inst.—when tho Bank had to repay the money recently borrowed from the market—were doomed to disappointment, the snm in question being held by the other banks in order to meet the usual "end of month" requirements and heavy revenue absorptions by the Government. Dealers had,in faot, to have recourse to the Bank, where renewals were granted and fresh sums lent, at 4$ %, and where bills were discounted at 4 % Under these oondirions, it cannot be wondered at that discount rates remain very stiff, - two months' bills'being 4 % and three months' bills 3 7/8 to 15/16. In tact, bill discounting so far this year has not been the most profitable business, the usual "margin" being more marked by its absence than otherwise Even now. although full three months' bills fall due nearly two months after the usual April diabnrse- ments, it would be unwife to connt on a heavy fall in rat is, there being so many underlying ciroamstauces to be considered, including the amount of Japane e and otherWoreigc money at present in onr market. 3cme satisfaction may be gathered from the Bank retnrns of yesterday, for althongh the "proportion" of reserve is slightly lower, this is doe to an' increase in the deposits, for the reserve itself now staids at 26 } millions, a gain of two millions in the week, whilst "other deposits" show an increase of nearly three millions at 42 £ millions. Since these retorts were issued there have been farther additions to the Bank's stook ot gold, inolnding the receipt of over £50,()00 from Holland, this again being a ati-factory feature. The Frenoh and German exchanges a!o remain fairly steady at 25.16 and 20.50-51 respectively.
Stocks and Share*,

Th* pa t we.-k has been one of extraordinary depression, wh-oh has reflected itself in almost every market. The outlook on Moroccan aff.i-8, and the nffiortnnate posirioniirfo which the Government have got themselves by their hasty action in regard to the Transvaal Constitution and the Chinese labonr question, were of oonrse the main factors in bringing about tho i resent state of things. The very strength of 'heir m»jori*y is t rovirg a weakness, as it evidently contain* two parties of widely divergent. views on this and other questions.

The Government have however! climbed down as far as possible on the Chinese labour question by the admission that 'h'ey do no* pr-po-e t-> oanosl-tbe lioenoes already, uaned, which will not expire before May, 1907. by wh:oh time tho Transvaal will have become a self-governing colony. The Under Secretary for the Colonies was compelled to admit, in a phrase which is worthy of preservation, that "Chinese labmr on the Rtnd oonld not be olasaifisd as s'avery in the -extreme acceptation of the word with rut, some riskot terminological inexactitude." This beats even Glads'one's woid-juggling.The result of this annonneeme i been a very mneb better feeling in the markets, which is rt fleeted in a considerable improvement in prices of shades from the lowest. World's Gold Production.

Some interesting statistics have been published in relation to the world's gold production, which go to prove that the South Afrioan Chinese labonr question is ODB of world wide iuterest. The total production is given as follows : —
QUANTITY.
Production in Inc. or doo. 1905. againBt 1904.

(South Africa) J United States... Other countries(4 905,17") + 1,16 247 4.219,280 + 326,80" 41.383

Value ... £77,358 000 + 6,253,000 These figures make it dear that any oon- siderab'e redaction in the enormoas gold oat- pat from South Africa would have a very serions effect. As it is, the amount of gold does not keep pace proportionately with the amonnt of securities. This proportion is already too low, being, according to a paper contributed to the Statistical Sooiety, not more than abunto%. It is obvipus, therefire, that any con-iderable shrinkage in the gold output m ght have very serious oor sequences.
New Issue*.

Althongh money is sparse f ir ordinary purposes, it is'notable that new issues have been largely subh-onbed, and underwriters, wh > were "stuck" with ismes bronght forward some tim« a jo, have been freely placing them w th the public. The truth of it is that while big financiers sre gradging cf their fnnds owirg t) the political outlook, the general public have plenty of money to invest.
Gilt Edged Stocks.

The market or gilt edged stooks has participated in the general dulness which has prevaiiled throughout the week, ai d Consols are ■jfj down on the wpek at 90 f fur the acoonnt, >t ter havirg been ^ below that p-?ce: Other curities in 'hi. class a e now steadier. Foreign Bonds.
It was rnmoured yesterday that a financial cpregentative of the Rus-ian Government had arrived in Paris with a view tonggotiating fora loan, and on the strength of this Russian bonds
hardened to 85. They are now quoted at 81 ? Japanese Btooks are somewhat irregular, and the Fours are lower on the week at 90£. There have also boon declines in the o.ther Japanese is-ne».

div.head: Home Railways
div.p: A further increase in traffic ret mis of most of the lines this week affords additional evidence of the soundness of hume railway stocks, bnt notwithstanding these assurances there seem1, it le inclination among buyers to patronis0 this market. It is, however, safe to predict that i considerable rally in thin section cannot now be long delayed. The North Eastern have igain the best showing in the returns, with a gain of £9,629 on the top of an insrease in the corresponding week last year of £3,591. and the Midland and Norb Western report ■noreasea of £6 400 and £6,000 respectively. The Great Western receipts are lower by £ 1,500, bat against this must be set the fact '•hat la»t year this ompany had a gain of £ 0,100. For the half year to date the L. and V. W. leads with an increase of £48 000. The G. W. R., on the other hand, is £2,000 to the bad.

div.head: Americans
div.p: The American market has been qniet, chiefly owing to the holiday in oelsbration of the anniversary of Washington's birth, and the reports of the steel trade are not so satisfactory. There is a soarcity of orders for pig iron, and a decrease in the price of this important commodity in America is not unlikely. At the same rime, the works are fall of orders f ir acme) time to come, and it is impossible to say w)fat the result of the impending strike in the /Coal trade nuy be. Those who have recently returned from America report that in the bitnminona coal region a strike is inevitable, and this ia farther confirmed by cables from Pittsburg.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: There has been a large basinets dote at advancing prieps in the lower-priced Egyptian shares during the past week The want cf a larger and regular market in Egyptians U roach feP, and the announcement that Mr. Rollo, of the National Bank of Egypt, is entering the Stock Exohange, where. we believe, be is jo:"ing the important firm of Messrs. Steer, Lawfnrd and Co., is looked upon as helping in this direotion. Gossip is active as regards the report of the Estates Company, and produtions of a large dividend as well as an ample reserve fund have pat up the^e shares to pearly 2, and the Deferred to 8 £- 9. Ir is a ticipated that these latter will receive 10to 12s. dividend, and they have bean in special demand, though the latent prioe bronght some sellers.

Rumonra are afloat ot the early heightening of the Nile dam, which is predicted in consequence of the cementing of the river in front of the dam to prevent Boonring, which, it is noted, is now taking place. There ia no doubt that if those rumours prove oorreot, it will lead to further great interest in Egyptian land properties.

Khedivial M iil Ordinary have been in large demand from Egypt and France, the price rising rapidly to 37s. 6d. buyers, but they are now slightly easier at 36s. Delta Land and Investment are up to 8 buyers. Egyptian Land and General Trust have tbanged hands in a line at d'sconnt, also at £ discount. National Bank of Egypt are distinctly easier at 27 £ £, and Agricultural Banks at 10. New A„gronltnral Barks close 9 £, Daira Ordinary have sagged away . 17 £, and the Deferred to 104 nominal. Delta Preference bearer are unaltered at 11 £. Union Fono:6 e are steady at 6 |, but Abyssinians are dnll and easier at £ premium.

Corporation of Western Egypt remain H premium, and D-iira Sugar are unchanged.at 4 |—5. It is curious to note that although Khedivial Mail Steamship Ordinary shares are s > m :ch In demand on various rumours, the Pref-rence i-haree are qnite unmentioned, and clone quite a nominal market at 4 £-§.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: The unsatisfactory attitude of the Government with regard to (South Africa is chiefly blamed for the lifeless- state of the market for the mining shares of tliat country, and until we see a more rational po'ioy outlined by thr-se in authority than at present promised, there is little hope of an increase of business in this direotion. It is satisfactory to note that to-day a better tone has prevailed as a result cf Mr Churchill's statement with respeot to th« Chinese ordinance. Rand Mines are to night quoted 6^, after touching 6 -fg, and East R rods are 9/32 higher at 5 §. In most of the Sinth African shares higher prices are now raling.

In the Egyptian section them has been little alteration in the price ot Ni'e Valleys, and the shares are onmentioned at 6s. Egyptian Mines Exploration are slightly lower andt 7s.-8s, ai d North Niles at Is. 6d.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.andamp;O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.andamp;O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: LIDO (VENICE) LIDO
div.p: From Vernon or Lido, 12 min by steamboat. Climatic Station and Sea Baths, with Chinesitherapic Institute. Express between the station and Lido for the hotels.

div.head: BAGNI LIDO
div.p: The most important bathing station in Italy. ____ Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic institute. Concerts daily, frequented by the highest classes of society.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies andamp; chalets. 200 rooms andamp; saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.

div.head: St. Moritz (Engadine) Switzerland. The Grand Hotel St. Moritz.
div.p: A new first class hotel with every modern convenience.
Address all inquiries to THE MANAGER.

div.head: LAKE OF COMO (Cernobble.) GRAND HOTEL VILLA D'ESTE
div.p: First-class hotel, finest situation on the Lake. Immense park and garden. Moderate charges. Omnibus at Como station.
T. Domben, Manager.

div.head: COMO "PLINIUS" GRAND HOTEL,
div.p: On the border of the Lake with beautfiul Garden and large Terraces. Magnificent Palace, built for the purpose of an Hotel, with the most complete comfort. Opened March, 1899. Very reasonable prices. English church.
Proprietor: J. De Glacomi, Manager of Gd. Hotel Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz, Engadine, Switzerland.
Manager: C. Scrobbi, of Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz.

div.head: LUGANO (Lake of Lugane) GRAND HOTEL METROPOLE ET MONOPOLE.
div.p: STRICTLY FIRST CLASS.
A BROCCA, Proprietor.
Also of the GRAND HOTEL, LUGANO.

div.head: LOCARNO THE GRAND HOTEL.
div.p: OPEN ALL THE YEAR.

Strictly first class. Every modern comfort. Terminus of the St. Gothard Railway. Magnificent winter and spring Resort. Best stopping place on the Italian lakes. Beautiful walks excursion English Chruch. Tennis and Golf. Central Heating.

div.head: LUCERNE HOTEL DE L'EUROPE
div.p: Comfortable family hotel, charmingly situated, known for its quietness, Extensive view of Lake and Mountain scenery. Newly furnished, every modern comfort, lift, electric light, throughout, grand hall and covered terraces, beautiful garden, table d'Hotel at small tables, moderate terms.
New proprietors, Blorn Bros.

div.head: Hotel TIVOLI pension.
div.p: Beautiful situation overlooking the Lake.
FIRST CLASS.
Every modern comfort
Moderate charges.

div.head: INNSBRUCK (Tyrol) CARL KAISER'S PENSION-HOTEL
div.p: Splendid situation, overlooking river and valley, surrounded by fruit, conifer and rose gardens, modern comforts and home-like, Library, English and American papers, baths, carriages, good Table and sanitary arrangements.

Specially suitable for those requiring rest, quietness, and change of air. Capital headquarters for excursions. Post telegraph, telephone, dark room, terms moderate for either short or long stay. English spoken. Apply for prospectus.

div.head: INTERLAKEN Regina Hotel,
div.p: JUNGFRAUBLICK.
Unrivalled position. FIRST CLASS. Thoroughly renovated suites and rooms with private baths.
Central heating. Every modern comfort.
J. Oesch.
Proprietor and Manager.

div.head: CHATEAU D'OEX THE GRAND HOTEL.
div.p: The newesty and most up-to-date, thoroughly First Class and replete with every modern comfort.
ELECRTIC LIGHT, CENTRAL HEATING, PRIVATE BATHS.

div.head: HOTEL BERTHOD.
div.p: The most comfortable first class family hotel.
EVERY MODERN COMFORT.
Berthod Brothers Proprietors.

div.head: ATHENS HOTEL DE LA GRANDE BRETAGNE
div.p: Special Office in the Hotel for Railway and Steamship
Tickets: also Post Office.
E. Lampsa, proprietor.

div.head: TOURIST AGENCY. POLEMY BROS., ATHENS.
div.p: 2. Philellenic Street (corner of Constitution Square), Conducted Tours for visiting Greece, Ionian Islands, Islands of the Archipelago, Asia Minor, Turkey, Palestine and Egypt.

div.head: CORFU GRAND HOTEL D'ANGLETERRE ET BELLE VENISE
div.p: Only first-class Hotel in Corfu with magnificent Garden. Fashionable modern Family Hotel. View of the Sea and lovely landscapes. Quietest, healthiest, and highest situation. Is the only Hotel situation in the highest part of Corfu.
Jean Garru and Freen, Proprietors.
